question: Does this paper involve the theory “A Model of Personal Informatics”?
searched_docs:
Their line of reasoning suggests that showing users
data  about  themselves  will  lead  them  to do  something,
presumably  something  different  from  and  better  than  what
they  are  already  doing.

Interestingly,  although  reflection  plays  a  prominent  role  in
personal informatics and related work, the final stage of Li
et  al.’s  [55]  model,  and  the  goal  of  much  similar  work,  is
action.

This  definition
carries  an  implicit  assumption  that  by  providing  access  to
data  that  has  been  “prepared,  combined,  and  transformed”
[55:561] for the purpose of reflection, reflection will occur.

Indeed,  the  idea  of  inciting  behavioral
change occurred implicitly in much of the papers reviewed
here.

personal informatics, many papers in our review that were

For  example,  showing  diabetics
blood sugar levels will increase their ability to manage their
condition  [25];  showing  frequency  of  shortcut  key  usage
will increase their usage [62]; showing mouse accuracy will
reduce  exaggerated  movements  and  improve  future
performance  [44].

web  browser  wherein  “the  user  is  able  to  notice  things
about  oneself  that  he  or  she  did  not  notice  before”
[65:4657].

Skillometers: reflective widgets 
that motivate and help users to improve performance. Proc UIST, 321-330.

Their line of reasoning suggests that showing users
data  about  themselves  will  lead  them  to do  something,
presumably  something  different  from  and  better  than  what
they  are  already  doing.

The Constitution of Reflection
Many  of  the  papers  in  this  review  described  interventions
designed  to  support  or  encourage  reflection  in  some  way.

For  example,  showing  diabetics
blood sugar levels will increase their ability to manage their
condition  [25];  showing  frequency  of  shortcut  key  usage
will increase their usage [62]; showing mouse accuracy will
reduce  exaggerated  movements  and  improve  future
performance  [44].
evidence:
Their line of reasoning suggests that showing users
data  about  themselves  will  lead  them  to do  something,
presumably  something  different  from  and  better  than  what
they  are  already  doing.

However,  these  papers  also  varied  in  the  degree  of
prescribing  exactly  of  what  that  behavioral  change  should
consist, raising comparisons with persuasion.

Proc 
CHI Ext. Abst., 4489-4492. 58.Li, I., Froehlich, J., Larsen, J.E., Grevet, C., and 

Ramirez, E. (2013).

Model of Personal Informatics Systems. Proc CHI, 557–
566. 56.Li, I., Dey, A.K., & Forlizzi, J.

Interestingly,  although  reflection  plays  a  prominent  role  in
personal informatics and related work, the final stage of Li
et  al.’s  [55]  model,  and  the  goal  of  much  similar  work,  is
action.

Indeed,  the  idea  of  inciting  behavioral
change occurred implicitly in much of the papers reviewed
here.
